metadata.subject: Call to Action! The impact of funding decline on female empowerment through the FC2 female condom and the increase of HIV/AIDS

organizations: United States Agency for International Development
Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health
Universal Access to Female Condoms (UAFC) Joint Programme
United Nations Joint Programme on HIV/AIDS
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

relationships.description: Procurement relationship for FC2 female condoms
Procurement relationship for FC2 female condoms

relationships.entity_2: Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health
relationships.description: Chairman of the Department of Health Behavior and Society

analysis.purpose: To advocate for new donor partnerships to fund FC2 female condom procurement in Africa due to declining UNFPA and USAID funding
analysis.significance: Highlights the critical impact of funding cuts on HIV/AIDS prevention efforts in Sub-Saharan Africa and proposes a solution through donor partnerships

notable_quotes: When a male and female condom are both available in the same market the overall number of protected sex acts goes up with as much as 13%
For every dollar spent on the program, there was a cost savings of nearly $20

FC2 is the only currently available female-controlled product approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration that provides dual protection against unintended pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections
red_flags: Significant funding cuts to HIV prevention programs
Major unmet need for female condoms in African countries

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this public health advocacy document

illegal_activity.description: No illegal activity discussed - this is a legitimate public health advocacy document

public_knowledge.context: HIV/AIDS statistics and public health funding issues are typically matters of public record and media interest

analysis.summary: This advocacy report highlights the critical decline in funding for FC2 female condom procurement in Africa through UNFPA and USAID, detailing the severe impact on HIV/AIDS prevention efforts in Sub-Saharan Africa where women comprise 51% of people living with HIV, and proposes donor partnerships to address the funding gap.
